column1: The title of Ngugi wa Thiong'o's novel written in Gikuyu while he was detained is "Devil on the Cross."
Binyavanga Wainaina won the Caine Prize for African Writing in 2002 for his story 'Discovering Home'.
The title of Okot p'Bitek's influential work published in 1966 is "Song of Lawino."
The title of Okot p'Bitek's most famous work is "Song of Lawino."
The title of Okot p'Bitek's most famous work is "Song of Lawino."
The title of Meja Mwangi's debut novel, published in 1974, is "Going Down River Road."
The title of Ngugi wa Thiong'o's novel about post-independence Kenya's neocolonialism is "Petals of Blood."
The title of Grace Ogot's short story collection that established her reputation is "Land Without Thunder."

The title of Grace Ogot's best-known work is "The Promised Land."
Notable works written by Okot p'Bitek include:  Song of Lawino 1970 Song of Ocol 1971 Artist The Ruler 1973 Anti-Colonial Literature in East Africa 1980

Ngugi wa Thiong'o's notable works include:  Weep Not, Child 1964   The River Between 1965   A Grain of Wheat 1967   Petals of Blood 1977   Devil on the Cross 1980   Matigari 1986   Decolonising the Mind 1986   The Wizard of the Crow 2006   Something Torn and New 2009   Birth of a Dream Weaver 2016
Meja Mwangi's books that depict Nairobi's street children include:  The Cockroach Dance    Nairobi Heat    The Last Plague
Okot p'Bitek is known for several notable works, including:  Song of Lawino    Song of Ocol    The African Writer and His Community    The Bad Man    The Long River    Night of the Golden Butterfly

Notable novels by Ugandan women writers include:  Mukokya's Hope by Angela A. K. K. Asimwe  The Joys of Womanhood by Buchi Emecheta  Kintu by Jennifer Nansubuga Makumbi  The First Wife by Pauline N. K., Makumbi  Tropical Fish by Doreen Baingana

Some notable works by Ugandan authors include:  "Song of Lawino" by Okot p'Bitek   "God's Bits of Wood" by Ousmane Sembène (though not Ugandan, it is often included in discussions of East African literature)   "The Fortunes of War" by Susan Nalugwa Kiguli   "Black Mamba Boy" by Nadifa Mohamed (also not Ugandan but relevant in the context of East African literature)   "Americanah" by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (influential but Nigerian, notable in East African literary discussions)   "Let the Dead Lie" by Paul Ngorok   "Dreams in a Time of War" by Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o (Kenyan but often referenced in East African literature)   "Benin: The Novel" by Lillian Ajarova

Grace Ogot is a prominent East African writer known for her contributions to literature, particularly in the context of Kenya. Some notable works by Grace Ogot include:  The Promised Land   The Other Woman   Land Without Thunder   This Time Tomorrow   The Pot of Wisdom    These works explore themes of identity, societal change, and the complexities of gender relations in a post-colonial context. Ogot’s storytelling often draws upon oral traditions, reflecting the rich cultural heritage of her Luo background.
Paradise By the Sea Desertion Afterlives
Notable literary works by Binyavanga Wainaina include:  One Day I Will Write About This Place   The Male Dancer   Discovering Home   Nairobi Heat   The Dark Child   The Great African Novel

Ngugi wa Thiong'o is a prominent Kenyan author known for both his literary contributions and his political activism. Some notable works by Ngugi include:  A Grain of Wheat 1967  Petals of Blood 1977  Devil on the Cross 1980  Matigari 1987  Decolonising the Mind 1986  Wizard of the Crow 2006  Dreams in a Time of War 2010  Birth of a Dream Weaver 2016    These works cover a range of themes, including colonialism, social justice, and the struggles of post-colonial African identity. Ngugi’s shift from writing in English to writing primarily in Gikuyu also marks a significant aspect of his literary journey, emphasizing his commitment to cultural and linguistic decolonization.
Not My Time to Die "Sarah's Story"

Grace Ogot is a notable East African author known for her contributions to literature that depict Kenyan society and culture. Some of her significant works include:  The Promised Land 1966   Wavering Experiences 1975   The Years of the Locust 1988   The Golden Feather 1994    Additionally, she is recognized for her short stories and contributions to anthologies exploring themes of gender, tradition, and modernity. For those interested in exploring her works further, "The Promised Land" is often seen as a foundational text in East African literature.
The title of Ngugi wa Thiong'o's semi-autobiographical novel is "Dreams in a Time of War."
Meja Mwangi's notable book titles include:  Going Down River Road    The Law of the Night    The Last Plague    The Cockroach Dance    Kill Me Quick

Yolande Mukagasana is known for her notable autobiographical works which include:  - "Nobody Had a Name"   - "The Kiosk"   - "Leave the Grave Open"    These works reflect her experiences during the Rwandan Genocide and provide insight into the broader themes of survival, trauma, and identity.

Some specific works by Ngugi wa Thiong'o include:  Weep Not, Child   1964   The River Between   1965   A Grain of Wheat   1967   Petals of Blood   1977   Devil on the Cross   1980   Matigari   1987   Decolonising the Mind   1986   Wizard of the Crow   2006   Remembering Africa   1993   Globalectics: Theory and the Politics of Knowing   2012   The Perfect Nine: The Kanga and the Akimbo   2019
Desertion    Paradise    By the Sea    Afterlives

Abdulrazak Gurnah is known for several notable titles, including:  Paradise (1994)   By the Sea (2001)   Desertion (2005)   The Last Gift (2011)   After Lives (2020)    These works explore themes of displacement, colonialism, and identity, reflecting Gurnah's own experiences as a Tanzanian expatriate.

Meja Mwangi is a prominent Kenyan writer known for his works that often explore themes of urban life, social change, and the impacts of colonialism on African identity. Notable works by Meja Mwangi include:  - **"Going Down River Road"**   - **"The Cockroach Dance"**   - **"Strange Equations"**   - **"The Last Plague"**   - **"The Return of Shaka"**    These works showcase his engagement with both contemporary issues and traditional narratives, reflecting the complexities of Kenyan society and broader East African contexts.

Notable works by Meja Mwangi include:  The Cockroach Dance 1980   Going Down River Road 1976   The Last Plague 1981   A Grain of Wheat 1974   The Devil on the Cross 1980    These works encompass various themes such as socio-political issues, urban life, and the struggles of Kenyan society.
Kakwenza Rukirabashaija   Jennifer Nansubuga Makumbi   Samuel Kyeyune   Ibambe Kinyanjui   Bwesigye Bwa Mwesigire

Okot p'Bitek is a prominent Ugandan poet and writer known for several notable works, including:  Songs of Sorrow (1967)  Muted and Mute (1989)  World of the Ancestors (1994)  Language of the Oromo (1970)   His poetry often explores themes of identity, cultural pride, and the tensions between tradition and modernity.

Notable works by Ngugi wa Thiong'o include:  Weep Not, Child   The River Between   A Grain of Wheat   Petals of Blood   Devil on the Cross   Matigari   Decolonising the Mind   Wizard of the Crow   The Wizard of the Crow
Binyavanga Wainaina won notable awards for his work "Discovering Home" (2002) and "One Day I Will Write About This Place" (2011).
The title of Okot p'Bitek's influential work published in 1966 is "Song of Lawino."
Grace Ogot is a prominent East African writer known for her contributions to literature. Three notable works by her are:  The Promised Land 1966 Obak's Trials 1986 That Which Is Nots 1976

Ngugi wa Thiong'o's first novel is titled "Weep Not, Child."
